title: 109_hr6399
content: The Act titled "Strengthening Public Health Protections in Major Disasters and Emergencies Act" aims to protect the health and safety of individuals in disaster areas by amending the Robert T. Stafford Disaster Relief and Emergency Assistance Act. The Act defines an individual as including workers or volunteers who respond to disasters like Hurricane Katrina or Rita, including police officers, firefighters, EMTs, urban search and rescue team members, and other relief workers determined by the President. The Act defines individuals as those involved in disaster response, including workers in critical infrastructure, residents, employees, students, and others determined by the President. Medical institutions include hospitals and accredited medical schools. Programs described in subsection (b) are carried out for disaster areas. The President may carry out a program for the protection, assessment, monitoring, and study of individuals in disaster areas affected by substances of concern, ensuring they are informed and protected against potential health impacts. The program includes monitoring individuals in disaster areas for health impacts of substances, providing healthcare referrals as needed, and using information to prevent future health impacts. The program involves activities such as collecting environmental exposure data, conducting health examinations, establishing exposure registries, studying health impacts, and providing assistance with health coverage eligibility. The program involves timely commencement of activities for public health protection and effective monitoring. Participation in registries and studies is voluntary, with privacy protection measures in place. The President may carry out the program through cooperative agreements. The President may select a medical institution or consortium near the disaster area to carry out a program through a cooperative agreement. Selection criteria prioritize proximity to the disaster area and groups of individuals who worked or volunteered in response to the disaster. The President may select a medical institution or consortium near the disaster area to carry out a program through a cooperative agreement. The selected individual must have appropriate experience in environmental or occupational health, toxicology, safety, clinical protocols, health monitoring, epidemiological studies, mental health studies, and medical surveillance programs. The President shall involve interested and affected parties, including government agencies, disaster responders, local residents, businesses, schools, and healthcare providers in establishing and maintaining a program for medical surveillance and environmental exposure or disease registries. The President shall involve various parties in establishing and maintaining a program for medical surveillance and disease registries, ensuring privacy regulations are followed. Reports must be submitted periodically to the Secretary of Homeland Security. The President shall establish a program for medical surveillance and disease registries, ensuring privacy regulations are followed. Reports must be submitted periodically to relevant authorities and Congress. The National Academy of Sciences will report on health and environmental protection in the Hurricane Katrina and Rita disaster areas. The National Academy of Sciences will conduct a study on disaster area health and environmental protection in collaboration with relevant experts. The National Academy of Sciences will conduct a study on disaster area health and environmental protection, focusing on emergency planning, public outreach, state and local departments, workers responding to disasters, public health services, environmental justice, and health disparities. The report will include advice on monitoring and responding to chemical releases in disasters. The National Academy of Sciences will conduct a study on disaster area health and environmental protection, focusing on emergency planning, public outreach, state and local departments, workers responding to disasters, public health services, environmental justice, and health disparities. The study will include advice on monitoring and responding to chemical or substance releases in a disaster area to protect public health and safety. This includes methods of sample collection and analysis, health-based threshold levels, and response actions in case of threshold exceedance. The curr_chunk discusses procedures for providing monitoring results to government agencies, response personnel, and the public. It also outlines the responsibilities of Federal, State, and local agencies for collecting samples, analyzing data, and taking response actions in the event of a disaster. Additionally, it addresses the capabilities of the Federal Government for environmental monitoring and response in disaster situations, including terrorist attacks. Authorization of appropriations is provided for necessary funds to carry out specified issues by the Secretaries of Homeland Security, Health and Human Services, and the Administrator of the Environmental Protection Agency. SEC. 4. PREDISASTER HAZARD MITIGATION amended the Robert T. Stafford Disaster Relief and Emergency Assistance Act. SEC. 5. PREVENTIVE HEALTH SERVICES BLOCK GRANTS; USE OF ALLOTMENTS amended the Public Health Service Act to include community outreach and education programs for health disparities prevention.
